head.title: Throbs, Ripples and Screeches, All Built From Simplicity

hedline.hl1: Throbs, Ripples and Screeches, All Built From Simplicity

abstract.p: Jon Pareles reviews The Randy Warhols, Polara and Swoon 23 at Mercury Lounge (M)

block.p: With the three bands that played at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night, there was no telling which comes first, the song or the sound that envelops it. The Dandy Warhols, Polara and Swoon 23 all reach back to the Velvet Underground's primal art-punk fusion of drone, tune and noise. Around simple structures, they gather resonances and dissonances, making songs throb or ripple or screech.

The Dandy Warhols, from Portland, Ore., started their set with eight minutes of one chord over a steady-ticking drumbeat: strumming it into crescendos, letting keyboard glissandos dive through it and quietly intoning, ''Keep on doing what you're doing.'' From there, the band moved into songs that drew on three-chord rock and early psychedelia, using serene vocal harmonies, buzzing keyboard licks and poppy choruses of ''la-la'' and ''ba-ba-ba-bop.'' The band's 1990's twist is its lyrics, which are sardonic about their own alienation. One song sneers, ''I never thought you'd be a junkie because heroin is so passe.'' But the words are carried away in sheer sound, which swallows any pettiness in the richness of resonating chords.

From there, the band moved into songs that drew on three-chord rock and early psychedelia, using serene vocal harmonies, buzzing keyboard licks and poppy choruses of ''la-la'' and ''ba-ba-ba-bop.'' The band's 1990's twist is its lyrics, which are sardonic about their own alienation. One song sneers, ''I never thought you'd be a junkie because heroin is so passe.'' But the words are carried away in sheer sound, which swallows any pettiness in the richness of resonating chords.

Polara, from Minneapolis, is scrappier, a garage band unraveling at the edges. Ed Ackerson, its leader, writes and sings relatively straightforward songs about love and frustration. True to collegiate-rock style, Mr. Ackerson translates ambivalence into sonic tumult. Songs emerged from drones and ended in feedback; between verses, he made his guitar notes wah-wah and wriggle. But chaos never overwhelmed the tunes, which made a short set seem even shorter.

Swoon 23, also from Portland, Ore., is one of many bands (among them Mazzy Star and Elysian Fields) indebted to the Velvet Underground's songs with Nico. Swoon 23 floats Megan Pickerel's breathy voice over slow, tolling chords, seeking -- and usually finding -- a sense of ominous foreboding and timeless uncertainty in their brooding repetition.
